Everything you need to know BEFORE going vegan: The key ingredients you must have in your pantry when taking on the restrictive diet

item.title: Body language expert reveals Victoria and David Beckham looked 'naturally disconnected' despite putting on a VERY loved-up display at Men's Fashion Week amid divorce rumours
item.description: The former footballer and his designer wife put on an extraordinarily loved-up display on Sunday - despite sitting apart, with Vogue editor Edward Enninful sandwiched between them.
item.content:encoded:
They were reunited in London on Sunday after furiously denying rumours of an imminent split.

But despite arriving at the London fashion week show separately, it was David and Victoria Beckham's body language that really set tongues wagging.

The former footballer and his designer wife put on an extraordinarily loved-up display - despite sitting apart, with Vogue editor Edward Enninful intriguingly sandwiched between them.

The couple barely made eye contact during the Kent & Curwen Men's Fashion Weekshow, although Victoria was spotted reaching over the table to give David's hand a squeeze at one point and later shared a snap of them holding hands on Instagram next to a loveheart emoji.

And according to communications expert Judi James, their body language suggests they are trying to 'set the record straight'. 

Judi, author of The Body Language Bible, told MailOnline FEMAIL: 'Like most celebrity couples, Victoria and David have had rumours swirling around their marriage for years, meaning we've seen Victoria performing body language [public displays of affection] like this in what often looks like an attempt to set the record straight.

'In these poses, she and David fluctuate between moments of what look like natural disconnection (sitting with another guest between them) and moments of intensely romantic intimacy that leave the Vogue editor Edward Enninful wearing the slightly embarrassed grin of the one who is suddenly in full gooseberry role. 

'It's Victoria who appears to really work the loving rituals here, even sporting a facial expression that looks coyly flirtatious and besotted while David responds with an eye-crinkling "look of love".' 

1. 'Victoria is soaking up the moment of proximity' (above)

'Was David just popping off to the loo and touching his wife on the shoulder to get past? David grins here as he positions the touch gesture but Victoria replies with an fully affirming tie-sign [small signs that a couple use to communicate with one another silently when they are out in public].

'She is smiling ahead with a look of delight while she places one hand over her husbands to let him know she's enjoying and even soaking up the moment of proximity.'

 2. 'David looks less assured and more serious'

'While Victoria whispers (or shouts, depending on the level of noise at the venue) into Edward's ear David's facial expression looks less assured and more serious as he disconnects from the conversation. 

'It's interesting to see how the couple's signals change when they're not involved in direct communication. David's brows are pulled into a partial frown.'

3. What does Victoria's hair pull mean?

'Victoria's hair-twiddle looks like across between a flirtatious self-preen and a more anxious-looking self-comfort ritual,' notes Judi.

4. 'She's bypassing etiquette to perform a PDA'

'This moment of connect is created by Victoria as she pushes her hand out to touch David, bypassing all etiquette norms to stretch across Edward and register the kind of loving ritual that will form a tender PDA,' notes Judi. 

'Her fingers are curled and up to her mouth in a partial cut-off that makes her look cute, coy and almost shy here. Her facial expression makes her look like a besotted young bride rather than a wife and mother in a mature marriage and she's rewarded with full eye-attention from David and a wide, affectionate-looking smile.'

 

Victoria and David reunited following difficult week and split rumours

David made a low-key entrance at the event on Sunday, after returning from a trip to the States amid the flurry of divorce rumours, before Victoria was pictured making her arrival a short time later. 

The couple, who have been married for 19 years, later took their seats inside the show, but with Vogue Editor Edward Enninful sat between them.

They did put on a united front however, with David pictured smiling at his wife as she leaned over their mutual friend Enninful to touch his hand.

Victoria was dressed in a flowing white midi dress for the couple's first public outing together since the Royal Wedding on May 19, adding a pop of colour with her yellow heels.

David owns a major stake in heritage fashion brand Kent & Curwen brand along with business partner Simon Fuller.

His fashion designer wife shared a number of photos on her Instagram page as she supported her husband, telling fans she was 'so proud' of the 'beautiful collection'.  

Just 24 hours earlier, Victoria was  pictured looking sombre on Saturday as she was seen for the first time since the Beckham camp hit back at the divorce claims.

In pictures obtained exclusively by MailOnline, the 44-year-old designer was seen leaving a boutique hotel in the upmarket district of Mayfair in London on Saturday, making a quick exit as she hurried into her car. 

As the mother-of-four was in the English capital, her husband, 43, was more than 3,000 miles away in Miami on a business trip.

Their respective outings came after they were forced to shoot down rumours of an impending divorce.

After rumors of an impending split began racing around social media on Friday, Jo Milloy, a spokesman for Spice Girl-turned-designer Victoria, told the Daily Mail that the gossip was ‘absolute nonsense’.

Meanwhile former England football captain’s spokesman, Simon Oliveira, likewise dubbed the claims ‘embarrassing and laughable’.

Elsewhere, a spokesman for the couple was quoted as saying: ‘There is no statement due, no divorce, and a lot of Chinese whispers and fake social media news. This is all very bizarre and an embarrassing waste of time.’ The rumours were ‘a crock of s***’, he said. 

Since the rumours began to circulate, Victoria has been enjoying some quality time with her family, sharing several snaps with her brood on social media. However, she was on her own as she left a hotel in London on Friday with a strained expression. 

The mother-of-four looked typically chic for the outing, teaming an oversized blue shirt with a pair of figure-hugging leather trousers that accentuated her lean legs, whilst also donning her trademark towering heels. 

The Mail on Sunday revealed that when Victoria saw the social media rumours about her marriage, she jokingly asked husband David, who was away in America at the time: ‘Are you divorcing me?’

The designer was said to be bemused but cracked jokes about it with friends.

A friend of the couple said: ‘Victoria was taken aback, but she found the whole thing very funny. They have had a sense of humour about this because it’s so ridiculous.

‘They are stunned that so many people have believed it, and also stunned that it so quickly got around. They spoke about it and laughed a lot. They have absolutely no idea where or how it started. It’s quite the mystery.’

The Beckhams will show a united front next month when they appear as a family for the first time in an interview and shoot for Vogue magazine, sources have said.

As part of celebrations to mark the tenth anniversary of Posh’s clothing label, she, David, and their four children – Brooklyn, Romeo, Cruz and Harper – will be interviewed for the cover feature.

Sources at Condé Nast, the publishing house which owns Vogue, say they expect it to be one of their best-selling issues.

One said: ‘It is such a coup to get the whole family together for one really special interview. It will celebrate Victoria’s life as a businesswoman but also as a mother and a wife. Everyone is really excited, nobody more so than her.’

Claims the couple were planning to divorce circulated on social media earlier on Friday, prompting high street bookmaker Paddy Power to suspend betting on them separating. Paddy Power's move came despite there having been no suggestion the couple were having any marriage difficulties. 

David married Victoria wed in 1999, and the couple have four children together: Brooklyn, 19, Romeo, 15, Cruz, 13, and Harper, six.

The retired footballer player was in the US for a business trip earlier in the week to Miami to discuss his impending Major League Soccer team there. Yet, his time in Miami wasn't notable, a source told DailyMail.com. 'He was in for a meeting with his business partner in the soccer deal,' the source said. 'It was a quick in and out trip.'

David's lawyers were in court in Miami on Tuesday as the county was fighting for the right to sell his ownership group land for his new stadium. While he didn't make an appearance in court, he was probably in town for updates or to scout other property for his impending soccer stadium.

David secured the rights to Miami's MLS expansion team as part of his 2007 contract with the LA Galaxy, and exercised his option to pay $25million for the new franchise in 2014.

Initially scheduled to launch for 2016 or 2017, the yet unnamed team has faced financing and stadium deal delays, and may begin play in 2020.

Meanwhile, Victoria has been enjoying some quality family time in England, and took to Instagram on Saturday to share a sweet snap with sons Romeo and Cruz as well as daughter Harper and her parents Jackie and Tony Adams.

The doting mother-of-four - who is also famed for her eponymous fashion line - put on a typically chic display as she was clad in a pair of patent trousers and a white tee, tied in with pointed red stilettos.

Victoria beamed with delight as she embraced her youngest child Harper, who flashed a wide grin for the adorable image. Second son Romeo bore a resemblance to Cruz, as the brothers both sported white T-shirts and dark-wash bottoms. Victoria captioned the image: 'Fun dinner x kisses from us all x.'  

David also returned to social media following the scandal as he promoted his grooming brand House 99 with a typically dashing snap on Instagram on Friday. In the black and white image, the football icon posed up a storm as he displayed his heavily-inked physique in a form-fitting T-shirt.  

Plugging his brand new collection, the father-of-four captioned the image: '@House99 is gearing up, share your #GameReady looks.'

Shortly before his post, the former Manchester United ace shared his condolences following the death of celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain, who was found dead from a suicide on Friday.

He took to his Instagram story: 'Travel isn't always pretty. It isn't always comfortable. Sometimes it hurts, it even breaks your heart. But that's okay. The journey changes you; it should change you.' 

The touching message continued: 'It leaves marks on your memory, on your consciousness, on your heart, and on your body. You take something with you. Hopefully, you leave something good behind.' David ended the note with 'Rest in peace Anthony', alongside a folded hands emoji.
item.dc:abstract: The former footballer and his fashion designer wife put on an extraordinarily loved-up display on Sunday despite sitting apart, with Vogue editor Edward Enninful sandwiched between them. And according to Judi James, their body language (including 'tender PDAs', top left, and Victoria's 'coyness', bottom left) suggests they are trying to 'set the record straight'. She told MailOnline FEMAIL: 'Like most celebrity couples, Victoria and David have had rumours swirling around their marriage for years, meaning we've seen Victoria performing body language [public displays of affection] like this in what often looks like an attempt to set the record straight.'
item.dc:creator: Unity Blott
item.mi:shortTitle: The Beckhams' body language decoded amid divorce rumours

item.title: 'She thought she was going to die': Horrified mother shares 12-year-old daughter's gut-wrenching account of what happened when her school went into lockdown
item.description: Los Angeles mother Sarah Wine-Thyre tweeted that her pre-teen daughter's school was on lockdown last week and shared the girl's account of what happened.
item.content:encoded:
With 23 school shootings in the US since 2018 began — amounting to one shooting per week so far this year — the news that another school is on lockdown with an active shooter has become incredibly and devastatingly commonplace.

And many parents are heartbroken and horrified that that's the case, including Los Angeles mom Sarah Wine-Thyre, 49.

Last week, when the school that her 12-year-old daughter went into lockdown, Wine-Thyre decided to spotlight the sad new reality by tweeting her daughter's take on the whole thing.

'This afternoon, I received text alerts from my kids' school that they were on lockdown,' she wrote on Wednesday, June 6, later explaining that there was an 'unidentified intruder on campus.'

'I thought you might like to know what happens, from the perspective of my 12yo. I just picked her up from school and she was rattled and full of adrenaline.'

According to her 12-year-old daughter, 'A robot voice came over the speakers telling us to get into our classrooms. The teachers pulled down the blinds and made us crowd into the far corner of the classroom. 

'We were all so scared and lots of kids were crying. My [best friend] and I were holding each other. I hugged a kid who was really scared and crying really hard. 

'We thought we were going to die. I said just in case we die, let's remember all our good times. My [best friend] and I sang our favorite song to each other.'

Wine-Thyre added that she could see how distraught the kids were when she went to pick her daughter up.

'All the kids in the class were visibly shaken and giddy. They were still holding each other. I asked if they were given updates during the 45-minute ordeal,' she said.

'No,' said her daughter. 'Everything was really quiet because they want it to seem like no one is there so the intruder goes away. 

'We were all just crammed together for 45 minutes and then we heard helicopters overhead and we thought we were going to be bombed. THAT was even scarier.

'There was one spot where the blinds weren't down all the way and we kept staring at it expecting some man's face to look in and see us and come in and kill us. We couldn't stop staring at that window. 

'We've done drills but we knew this was for real,' the pre-teen went on. 'We were all sure we were going to die, Mom. I'm so glad we didn't die.' 

Wine-Thyre added that 'a child's experience of a lockdown is one of terror,' especially since they aren't given the same real-time updates as people on the outside.

'Plenty of people see this as "the price of freedom." It's appalling that we do this to kids,' she added. 

After the ordeal, Wine-Thyre said she emailed her daughter's teacher to thank them, but even knowing her kid was safe didn't calm her down. 

'I still kinda feel like I'm gonna throw up. I had more information about the nature of the lockdown that she did, but your parent mind just goes there,' she said. 

Her tweet has now been liked over 17,000 times and received hundreds of replies, opening up a discussion about gun violence in school.

When one commenter compared lockdown drills — though Wine-Thyre's daughter's lockdown was real, not a drill — to nuclear bomb drills experienced by earlier generations, the protective mother said there was no comparison.

'The nuclear terror — which was real, I was terrified of nuclear war as a kid even though we didn't do drills — was distant and foreign. Lockdown drills and active shooter drills are coming from within, with no warning. There is a difference.' 

She went on: 'It's manufactured crisis, not an act of god. Almost completely avoidable with common sense laws.

'The teachers in my family are constantly ruminating about how they will/would react in a school shooting situation, while they wonder about their own children's safety and lives. It's a nightmare calculus and would be unnecessary if we had decent laws.'

Dozens of other parents chimed in to share their own stories, recounting things their children said and did after experiencing a lockdown at their school.

'My daughter was in a lockdown drill,' wrote one. She has a processing disability and didn't understand what was happening. The teacher wouldn't explain. I got a series of terrified texts from her under a desk. When I got to the school they wouldn't let me in. It was hell.'

'My 5yo does active shooter drills but it's unnamed,' wrote one dad. He said that the little girl explained: 'We all cram into the playhouse, 27 of us there, and we have to be silent while the teacher stands by the door.' 

'The thought of dead kids in that playhouse rips me apart,' he said.

'My son had his first lockdown drill in pre-K (he’d just turned 4). The thought of my little fuzzy duckling and his friends with their tiny backpacks huddling under desks.... He had nightmares for weeks and didn’t even understand what had happened,' another mother added.

'My niece is a teacher & she literally said to me yesterday, "I go to work every day with the knowledge that one day I may have to place my body between a child & a bullet,"' added another Twitter user.  

Earlier last week, another school's lockdown procedure earned international attention due to the heartbreaking way they include the children.

Inside a kindergarten class in Somerville, Massachusetts hangs a sign with a nursery rhyme, which teaches the kids what to do in case of an active shooter.

The rhyme, sung to the tune of Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star, was posted by a man named Georgy Cohen, and millions have found it disturbing.

It reads: 'Lockdown, lockdown, lock the door / Shut the lights off, say no more. / Go behind the desk and hide. Wait until it's safe inside. / Lockdown, lockdown it's all done. Now it's time to have some fun!'' 

Many people commenting on the poem compared it to their own childhoods, during which they said the worst they had to worry about at school was a fire drill.

'This should not be handing in my soon-to-be-kindergartner's classroom,' Cohen wrote, adding that she didn't blame the school, but the current climate. 

'The school is doing exactly what they need to be doing, and I am glad for it,' she said. 'My issue is with the political & cultural factors that brought us to this sad state. Please talk to your legislators about the need for gun reform.'

She and Somerville Public Schools declined to identify the school, but district officials confirmed it was the work of one teacher and is not used across all of the city's schools.

The Somerville district enrolls about 5,000 students in a suburb north of Boston.

In a statement, Superintendent Mary Skipper and city Mayor Joseph Curtatone applauded the teacher's creativity, but lamented that lockdown drills have become as common as fire drills.

'As much as we would prefer that school lockdowns not be a part of the educational experience, unfortunately this is the world we live in,' they wrote. 'It is jarring - it's jarring for students, for educators and for families.' 

There has been almost one school shooting a week, on average, since January. Most recently, two people were injured by a gunman at Noblesville West Middle School in Noblesville, Indiana

The most recent fatal shoot was at Santa Fe High School in Santa Fe, Texas, when a shooter opened fire in an art room, leaving ten dead and another ten injured.

There have also been fatal shootings at Great Mills High School in Lexington Park, Maryland (March 20), Huffman High School in Birmingham, Alabama (March 7), Central Michigan University in Mount Pleasant, Michigan (March 2).

Deaths also occurred at Marshall County High School in Benton, Kentucky (January 23) and Winston-Salem State University (January 20).

But the worst shooting this year took place in Parkland, Florida, when a 19-year-old former student began shooting students and staff members with a semi-automatic AR-15 type rifle. In that event, 17 people were killed, and 17 others were injured.
item.dc:abstract: Los Angeles mother Sarah Wine-Thyre, 49, tweeted that her pre-teen daughter's school was on lockdown last week. She had the 12-year-old share her account of what happened and how she felt. The young girl said kids were crying and holding each other, and they were all worried that they were about to die. The school was put on lockdown because of an intruder, but students weren't told what was happening and had to remain quiet and hidden. Wine-Thyre said after school, the class was still 'visibly shaken and giddy' and holding each other. Also last week a picture of a lockdown-themed nursery rhyme hanging up in a Somerville, Massachusetts kindergarten class went viral. Sung to the tune of Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star, it teaches young children what to do in case of an active shooter.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Lankston
item.mi:shortTitle: 12-year-old's account of what happened when her school was on lockdown

item.title: 'When I'm feeling fire, I let the world know!' Iskra Lawrence shares a VERY racy video of herself strutting her stuff in nothing but an open trench coat and a nude thong
item.description: The 27-year-old model took to both Instagram and Twitter on Friday to share footage of herself modeling a pink coat and orange heels while doing sexy strut on set of her latest shoot.
item.content:encoded:
Iskra Lawrence left little to the imagination when she posted a racy video of herself showing off her famous figure in nothing but an open trench coat and a nude thong.  

The 27-year-old model took to both Instagram and Twitter on Friday to share footage of herself modeling a pink coat and orange heels while doing sexy strut on set of her latest shoot.

'When I’m feeling fire I let the world know,' she tweeted along with the clip. 

The video starts with Iskra holding her trench coat closed while doing a model walk for the camera. 

When she opens the trench, she covers her nether region with her hands while gazing at the camera.  

Iskra then turns around, giving viewers a glimpse of her bare derriere as her coat twirls around her. 

Many of her four million Instagram followers told her she looked fantastic in the clip, but she swiftly hit back at an online troll who commented: 'Wish you had bigger t**s.'

Iskra shared a grab of the comment on her Instagram Stories, writing: 'Wish you had bigger things to wish for [tears of joy emoji].'

Earlier in the day, she posted an Instagram Stories video of herself showing off one of the outfits she was wearing during the shoot.

'Today's first lil lewk,' she captained the clip, which shows her wearing a denim jacket over a sheer top and a light blue tulle skirt. 

Just a few days before, she showed off her curvaceous figure in a slew of throwback bikini snapshots from her vacation in the Maldives. 

The Aerie ambassador explained that the never-before-seen photos show her wearing a new bikini style that was just launched by the brand.   

'So when I posted this from my Maldives holiday, this Aerie collection wasn't out yet so I'm happy to announce this style - called the Henley - has dropped!' she wrote.  

'Can't wait to see all your unretouched swim pics so make sure you use #aeriereal because the real you is good enough!' 

Iskra looks happier than ever in the snapshots, which show her walking on the beach in the gray two-piece. 

The Aeri star opted to accentuate her ample cleavage by unbuttoning three of the five buttons on the $22 bandeau bikini top.   

Meanwhile, the high-waisted, V-cut bottoms rose up above Iskra's hips, highlighting her hourglass figure.

Iskra first posted photos of herself in the new bikini back in April, but she opted to share some more in honor of the swimsuit finally being available for purchase.    

She donned a variety of Aerie swimsuits during the trip, and she proudly showed them off while paddle-boarding and posing in front of the crystal clear water.

'When I’m feeling fire I let the world know,' she tweeted along with the clip. The video starts with Iskra holding her trench coat closed while doing a model walk for the camera. When she opens the trench, she covers her nether region with her hands while gazing at the camera. Iskra then turns around, giving viewers a glimpse of her bare derriere as her coat twirls around her.

item.title: Move over strawberries and cream! VIP guests and chefs share snaps of the jaw-dropping food served at the French Open – including a tennis ball-shaped EXPLODING dessert
item.description: Upmarket caterers created spectacular dishes for 2018's Roland-Garros contest. Dishes included a tennis ball made of chocolate containing popcorn and cream, and the Champagne flowed.
item.content:encoded:
The tennis may have been the main event but chefs at the French Open ensured that the food on offer for VIP guests was just as captivating as the action on the court.

Well-heeled invitees to the world-renowned tennis tournament - where Rafael Nadal and Simona Halep both triumphed in three sets on Sunday - shared photos of the spectacular array of dishes served up at Roland-Garros on Instagram.

Many of the fine dining meals were created by upmarket French caterers Potel et Chabot, the official caterers of the 2018 competition.

Dishes included a jaw-dropping exploding tennis ball-shaped dessert, as well as an intricate cake with a butterfly design. 

The Champagne was also flowing nicely, with s a few photographs capturing bottles lavishly on display.

Away from the main restaurants, cafes and terraces open to the general public, there are special VIP areas for corporate and special guests where the dining kicks up a notch.

There are at least three areas in which VIPs can enjoy a spectacular 'gastronomic lunch': Le Pavillon Tennis, La Tribune, and Le Salon Légende.

Corporate hospitality tickets, which include a 'gourmet luncheon', range from €490 for a first-round match to a whopping €1790 for the men's final.

French celebrities including It Girl Jeanne Damas and models Estelle Lefébure and Marie-Ange Casta were snapped at the event, which was on for two weeks.
item.dc:abstract: Upmarket caterers created spectacular dishes for 2018's Roland-Garros contest. Dishes included a tennis ball made of chocolate containing popcorn and cream (top right), as well as a giant Choux Religieuse (top centre), an intrucate butterfly-themed dessert (top left), a floral starter of vegetables and caviar (bottom centre) and a beautiful dessert topped with a dark chocolate feather (bottom right). The Champagne was also flowing at the competition (bottom left), the men's final of which was won by Rafael Nadal on Sunday in three sets.
item.dc:creator: Imogen Blake
item.mi:shortTitle: VIP guests share pics of jaw-dropping food served at the French Open

item.title: Shrimps designer Hannah Weiland whose clothes are loved by Alexa Chung ties the knot with her Guinness brewing heir fiancé in a VERY stylish country wedding
item.description: Shrimps designer Hannah Weiland tied the knot with Arthur Guinness in Bradford on Avon in front of a flock of glamorous guests including former Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman and Laura Bailey.
item.content:encoded:
She has dressed everyone from Alexa Chung to Poppy Delevingne.

So it's little surprise that the wedding of Hannah Weiland, the woman behind celebrity favourite Shrimps, was an achingly stylish affair.

The London-based designer tied the knot with brewing heir Arthur Guinness over the weekend in front of a flock of glamorous guests including former Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman and model Laura Bailey.

Pictures shared on Instagram under the hashtags #shrimpsandguinness show guests sipping on Guinness, playing pétanque and dancing the night away in a glittering marquee at the jaw-dropping nuptials.

The couple said their vows at a small church in Bradford on Avon - where Weiland's parents are from - before a lavish reception at nearby Belcombe Court.

The bride stunned in a bohemian-style tiered dress with a long veil as she walked down the aisle alongside the couple's pet poodle, Lionel McGruff.

The stylish congregation also included actress Matilda Sturridge, writer Scarlett Curtis - daughter of Love Actually director Richard - and one of the Duchess of Cambridge's favourite designers, Penelope Chilvers - who noted that it was 'a first to see dogs in the congregation'.

The church door was decorated in a huge floral display by Scarlet & Violet, with the father of the bride gushing that 'everyone was blown away by their abundance and beauty' in a heartfelt Instagram post.

A pop-up pub called Arthur's Arms in the groom's honour - serving Black Velvets and Guinness, naturally - was the brainchild of creative consultant Matilda Goad who also organised the stunning place settings.

Inside the jaw-dropping marquee, tables were festooned with wild flowers and peonies by London florist Wetherly, while Rochelle Canteen was responsible for the catering.

The cake was a show-stopping affair by Lily Vanilli, topped with quirky bride and groom figurines by Twisted Knits.

And the stylish couple even had their very own 'wedding coat of arms' designed by illustrator Poppy Chancellor - featuring a shrimp, pints of Guinness, one of Hannah's iconic beaded handbags, and guest starring their pet poodle.

After the evening's festivities, guests finished off their weekend with a game of pétanque.
item.dc:abstract: Shrimps designer Hannah Weiland tied the knot with Arthur Guinness (left) in Bradford on Avon in front of a flock of glamorous guests including former Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman and model Laura Bailey. Pictures shared on Instagram under the hashtags #shrimpsandguinness show guests such as Scarlett Curtis and Matilda Sturridge (right) sipping on Guinness, playing pétanque and dancing the night away at the jaw-dropping nuptials.
item.dc:creator: Unity Blott
item.mi:shortTitle: Fashion designer ties the knot in a VERY stylish country

item.title: Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson is praised by fans for sharing an intimate snap of his partner nursing their daughter - while he 'feeds mama her dinner'
item.description: Parents have praised actor Dwayne The Rock Johnson after he shared a picture of himself feeding his partner Lauren Hashian as she breastfed their two-month-old daughter Tiana.
item.content:encoded:
Parents have praised actor Dwayne The Rock Johnson after he shared a picture of himself spoon feeding his partner Lauren Hashian as she nursed their two-month-old daughter Tiana.

The heartwarming snap was soon posted to Facebook parenting page 'The Badda** Breastfeeder', where the Fast And Furious star was inundated with comments from mothers and fathers.

Many commended the former professional wrestler, who is also father to daughter Simone, 16, with his ex-wife Dany Garcia two-year-old Jasmine with fiance Lauren, for his 'team work', before sharing their own experiences.

Taking to Facebook, the parenting forum wrote, 'And this is how it's done. Thank you Dwayne The Rock Johnson', before sharing his post. 

The 46-year-old father-of-three had shared a snap showing him spoon-feeding Lauren while on his knees, as she breastfed their two-month-old daughter Tia.

He captioned the snap: 'I'll handle this business! Mama has her hands full nursing/feeding Baby Tia, so I'm feedin' mama her dinner. My pleasure. 

'So much respect to her and all mamas out there holding it down and running things. Just landed and good to get all my girls settled in.

'Now, I gotta go satisfy my own appetite.. Iron Paradise, here I come.'

And parents flocked to the Facebook post, which quickly received 22,000 likes, 2,000 comments and a staggering 12,000 shares.

One mother wrote: 'This is a stunning photo capturing a moment that will be cherished forever'.

Another added of Dwayne and their own husband: 'Perfect partners, perfect daddies and perfect gentlemen #breastfeedingisawesome'

And many shared their own experiences, with one writing: 'Do you remember doing this for me?! Seems so long ago now doesn't it!'

Another added of her partner: 'Many thanks for unconditional love and support with our breast feeding journey..20 months and so on!'

'My husband does this for me while I’m breast feeding our 2 week old little girl Ava,' another added.

Praising the team work, one wrote: 'From one breastfeeding mama to another.. I remember those times well now I manage to get some food between times team work! X'.

Another added: 'Remember the first week with Laila. You pretty much fed me that entire week, and one wrote: 'I remember you looking after me like this'.

In April The Rock and his partner Lauren Hashian announced the birth of daughter Tiana Gia.

The actor announced the newborn's arrival by sharing a sweet picture of himself cradling the infant to his bare chest.

The father-of-three said in a caption that he was 'Blessed and proud to bring another strong girl into this world.'

He wrote: 'Tiana Gia Johnson came into this world like a force of nature and Mama labored and delivered like a true rockstar.

'I was raised and surrounded by strong, loving women all my life, but after participating in baby Tia’s delivery, it’s hard to express the new level of love, respect and admiration I have for and all mamas and women out there.'

He also shared his advice for other expectant fathers, writing: 'Word to the wise gentlemen, it’s critical to be by your lady’s head when she’s delivering, being as supportive as you can.. holding hands, holding legs, whatever you can do. 

'But, if you really want to understand the single most powerful and primal moment life will ever offer - watch your child being born. Its a life changer and the respect and admiration you have for a woman, will forever be boundless.'

The Fast And Furious star also has daughter Simone, 16, with his ex-wife Dany Garcia and two-year-old Jasmine with fiance Lauren. 

The Baywatch actor, born Dwayne Johnson, also made a promise to his newest child.

'And to my third and youngest daughter, Tiana Gia - like I did when your two older sisters Simone Alexandra and Jasmine Lia were born, you have my word, I’ll love, protect, guide and make ya laugh for the rest of my life.

'Your crazy dad has many responsibilities and wears many hats in this big ol’ world, but being your dad will always be the one I’m most proud to wear.

'Oh and one more thing.. you’re gonna love rollin’ in daddy’s pick up truck.'
item.dc:abstract: Parents have praised actor Dwayne The Rock Johnson after he shared a picture of himself feeding his partner Lauren Hashian as she breastfed two-month-old Tiana (left). The heartwarming snap was soon posted to Facebook parenting page 'The Badda** Breastfeeder', where the Fast And Furious star was inundated with comments from mothers and fathers. Many commended the former professional wrestler, who is also father to daughter Simone, 16, with his ex-wife Dany Garcia two-year-old Jasmine with fiance Lauren, for his 'team work', before sharing their own experiences.
item.dc:creator: Carol Driver
item.mi:shortTitle: The Rock praised for snap of him feeding his partner nursing daughter

item.title: The REAL reason for Kate's polo dash! Proud Duchess ran to congratulate William's team after they won their polo match - and shared air kisses with his VERY friendly teammate
item.description: Photos of the Duchess, 36, dashing across the grass at the Beaufort Polo Club yesterday, showed the royal making her way to congratulate Prince William and his team after they won.
item.content:encoded:
When the Duchess of Cambridge was pictured sprinting from her seat on a grass bank at the Maserati Royal Charity Polo on Sunday, it was assumed she had been playfully running after her children.

But pictures taken from a different angle at the Beaufort Polo Club show how the Duchess was eagerly running to congratulate William and his team mates after the game. 

As she made her way to her husband's side, the Duchess stopped to greet veteran polo player Malcolm Borwick who has captained the England team and played for Prince Harry's Sentabale charity cup. 

The professional previously revealed he'd even offered to give Meghan, the new Duchess of Sussex, some lessons after she took an interest to the sport while dating Harry. 

And he seemed delighted to see the Duchess yesterday, who paused to dole out air kisses and a hug as she made her way to her husband's side.  

After yesterday's match, Kate was seen rising from the place where she had been sitting next to little Charlotte and run down the grass bank at great speed.

In the distance to the right - by the row of white marquees - Malcolm could be seen standing apparently shouting out to her, beckoning her over.

As Kate ran across the grass it appeared that Charlotte cried out after her from behind, and she stops, turned around and waited momentarily for Charlotte to join her at her side.

After waiting for the little princess to join her, Kate turned back to Malcolm and gave him an air-kiss on both sides of his cheek, and a warm hug.

Kate and her children delighted fans with a surprise appearance on Sunday afternoon as she, George and Charlotte descended on Tetbury for a day of family fun.

Dressed casually in a £39.99 Zara dress and Russell & Bromley wedges, Kate looked every inch the doting mother as she kept a watchful eye on George, four and his cousins Isla and Savannah Phillips.

At one point, mischievous Charlotte made Kate and Autumn Phillips collapse into fits of giggles as she performed an impressive headstand, while a shy George watched on.

The match was arrange to raise funds and awareness for two charities - the Royal Marsden, which the Duke supports as president, and Centrepoint, of which he is patron.
item.dc:abstract: Photos of the Duchess, 36, dashing across the grass at the Beaufort Polo Club yesterday seemed to show the mother-of-three running after her children. But it turns out the proud royal was dashing to congratulate her husband Prince William after his team won. She stopped along the way to share air kisses and a hug with his team-mate, England player Malcolm Borwick (right and inset).
item.dc:creator: Siofra Brennan
item.mi:shortTitle: The REAL reason for Kate's polo dash!

item.title: Revealed: How the svelte Duchess of Cambridge lost her baby weight in just SEVEN weeks after giving birth to Prince Louis (and it's all down to good genes)
item.description: The mother-of-three looked impeccably slimline yesterday as she enjoyed a family day out at the Beaufort Polo Club in Gloucestershire, just seven weeks after Prince Louis was born.
item.content:encoded:
She gave birth to her third child Prince Louis seven weeks ago, but the Duchess of Cambridge has already snapped back to her svelte pre-pregnancy shape. 

The mother-of-three looked impeccably slimline yesterday as she enjoyed a family day out with George and Charlotte at the Beaufort Polo Club in Gloucestershire.

Kate, 36, sported a fitted striped Zara dress with a matching belt that accentuated her slim waist, and seemed to have lost weight since appearing at the royal wedding just three weeks ago. 

According to midwife Laura Spicer of The Women’s Health Clinic it is possible for some new mothers to snap back into shape quickly, and it's down to a combination of pre-existing fitness and good genes. 

'Some women definitely can snap back into shape. However, if you are fit and have had a healthy pregnancy with a normal BMI it is possible to be similar to your pre-pregnancy body shape. 

'It’s also got a lot to do with genetics, so if Mum recovered well you’re more likely to as well.'

Scroll down for video 

However, she added that it is remarkable that Kate's slimmed down so quickly given this is her third baby.

'It is very normal for the majority of women to take up to a year to lose any excess weight gain,' she said. 

'Indeed, many women’s body shapes will never be the same as prior to pregnancy, from an enlarged rib cage to bigger breasts, it will take women a while to get used to their new physique. 

Often with every baby it gets harder to lose the weight as quickly as the last.   

'It’s amazing that thousands of years ago these signs of becoming a mother actually used to make women more attractive, as it was a sign of their fertility.' 

She added that Kate's weight loss is also likely down to her following a healthy diet since giving birth, which can be difficult in the first weeks.  

'Cutting down on all the things your body can crave after delivery is hard, we normally crave carbs and comfort foods, especially if breast feeding you will be looking for extra calories,' she explained. 

'If you can avoid this and snack on health foods and balanced healthy dinners you are far more likely to lose the excess weight quicker. 

'We certainly wouldn’t recommend excessive dieting and exercise over breastfeeding and bonding with your newborn. 

'Some women also use waist trainers or Spanx as a girdle to help the stomach deflate.'

The Duchess of Cambridge welcomed Prince Louis to the world on 23rd April and the photos of her looking impeccably coiffed on the steps of the Lindo Wing later the same day caused worldwide debate.

Commentators said seeing the Duchess in heels and full make-up within hours of going through labour put unrealistic pressure on new mothers. 

Her next public appearance was at Harry and Meghan's wedding on 18th May, less than four weeks after giving birth, still showing a hint of her post-pregnancy curves, the Duchess looked.

However, just three weeks on it seemed as if she was back to her pre-pregnancy shaped as she chased around after her two older children George and Charlotte.
item.dc:abstract: The mother-of-three looked impeccably slimline yesterday as she enjoyed a family day out at the Beaufort Polo Club in Gloucestershire, just seven weeks after Prince Louis was born. Left to right: Pregnant with Prince Louis, looking impossibly polished within hours of giving birth, looking slim less than four weeks later and back to her pre-pregnancy shape after just seven weeks.
item.dc:creator: Siofra Brennan
item.mi:shortTitle: Duchess of Cambridge lost her baby weight in just SEVEN weeks

item.title: The ORIGINAL royal rule-breaker! Sweet picture shows Prince Harry covering Princess Beatrice's mouth on the Buckingham Palace balcony - 30 years before Savannah Phillips followed in his footsteps
item.description: The unearthed photograph from September 1990 shows how Prince Harry, on his sixth birthday, covered two-year-old Beatrice's mouth while on the Buckingham Palace balcony.
item.content:encoded:
Savannah Phillips stole the show at this year's Trooping the Colour ceremony - by covering Prince George's mouth while the national anthem was playing.

But an unearthed photograph from September 1990 shows how Prince Harry was in fact the original royal rule-breaker, covering cousin Princess Beatrice's mouth while on the Buckingham Palace balcony.

The picture shows a young Harry, on his sixth birthday, putting his hand over two-year-old Beatrice's mouth as they watched the Battle of Britain 50th Anniversary Parade nearly 30 years ago. 

The cheeky young royals were joined on the balcony by Princess Diana, dressed in vibrant green, and other members of the royal family, including the Duchess of York.

Scroll down for video  

It comes after a new generation of young royals stole the limelight at the Trooping the Colour ceremony on Saturday.  

Savannah Phillips, the Queen's great-granddaughter, appeared unimpressed with Prince George's endless chatter and slapped a hand over his mouth to keep him quiet.

Seven-year-old Savannah, the daughter of Peter Phillips and granddaughter of Princess Anne, also made a shushing motion at little George. 

It appeared the young prince couldn't contain his excitement as he watched the planes zoom overhead.

But the Duke of Cambridge, standing behind them, looked unimpressed by the pair's antics on the balcony and gave them a very disapproving look.

Back in 1990 though, Diana seemed less concerned by young Harry's antics, as they also watched a fly past from the Buckingham Palace balcony. 

During the event, Diana was seen doting on her son, who later sweetly embraced cousin Beatrice.

They were joined by the Queen on the balcony, along with King Baudouin of Belgium. 

Eagle-eyed royal watchers were quick to pick up on the similarities between Savannah trying to shush second cousin George, and Harry covering Beatrice's mouth three decades ago. 

One wrote on Twitter: 'Prince Harry & Princess Beatrice vs. Savannah & Prince George. Runs in the family!'

Another added: 'History repeating itself! Blows my mind'. 

Meanwhile, a royal fan account posted on Instagram: 'Yes, you have to start practicing early how to shut mouths..'

On Saturday, the Duchess of Cambridge had to step in when Princess Charlotte became overwhelmed by all the excitement.

The youngster burst into tears and had to be comforted by her mother, who tenderly picked her up and gave her a cuddle.

But ever the professional, little Charlotte quickly composed herself.

Peter Phillips, Savannah's father, is the only son of Princess Anne and her first husband Mark Phillips.

Like the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, he married his Canada-born wife Autumn at St George's Chapel in Windsor in 2008.
item.dc:abstract: The unearthed photograph from September 1990 shows how Prince Harry, on his sixth birthday, covered two-year-old Beatrice's mouth while on the Buckingham Palace balcony (top). The pair were joined by Princess Diana and the Duchess of York for the Battle of Britain 50th Anniversary Parade. It comes after Savannah Phillips, seven, stole the show at this year's Trooping the Colour ceremony by covering Prince George's mouth while the national anthem was playing (bottom).
item.dc:creator: Emily Chan
item.mi:shortTitle: Prince Harry covering Beatrice's mouth on Buckingham Palace balcony

item.title: Are YOU eating right for your body type? Fitness star Camilla Akerberg, 28, reveals the perfect diet and workout for three key physiques - and the characteristics of each one
item.description: FEMAIL speaks to Australian personal trainer, fitness coach and nutrition coach, Camilla Akerberg , about the three body shapes and the ideal approach to health and fitness for each one.
item.content:encoded:
Every day it seems as though a new fad diet, superfood or quirky workout is flooding social media feeds the world over.

And while these regimes may work for some, there is a far simpler way to stay in shape both inside and out. 

The trick? Eating and exercising for your particular body shape.   

Here, FEMAIL speaks to Australian personal trainer, fitness coach and nutrition coach, Camilla Akerberg, about these body shapes and the ideal approach to health and fitness for each one.

Scroll down for video 

WHAT IS YOUR BODY TYPE? 

'We are all different from each other and react differently to training and nutrition. If you are more curvy, following your skinny, lean friend's diet and exercise regime might not be the best for your body's needs,' Ms Akerberg said. 

'Your body is unique in every way, however, we can stereotype traits in bodies and categorise them into body types. 

'The most used body type system today is the Heath-Carter anthropometric somatotype system' which focuses on fat, muscle and the body's capacity to change with physical activity. 

'This system breaks down all the unique body types into three main stereotypes: The Ectomorph, the Mesomorph and the Endomorph.

'Your body type can also be calculated with the help of skin folds, measurements and weight. In my program I have a body type test that you can do if you are unsure. 

'However, most people will know their body well enough to find out which one of the three body types is the dominant one for them - although you are most likely to have qualities from several body types.' 

THE ECTOMORPH - THE SKINNY MINNY

Celebrity Ectomorphs: Kendall Jenner, Kate Moss, Cameron Diaz 

What is an ectomorph?   

'An ectomorph person is naturally skinny with long limbs. They have a smaller bone-structure (skinny wrists, skinny ankles),' Ms Akerberg said. 

'As they tend to have a high metabolic rate, they lose fat easily and they find it harder to put on muscle. These people are often a bit hyper and excessively fidgety (which increases their non-exercise activity thermogenesis.

'This contributes to that fast metabolism. They are often quite picky eaters but can often eat a lot without seeming to put on weight. These people are often quite high in cortisol.'

How should they train?    

Ectomorphs naturally lack muscle and strength. 

'To attain a more fit look they need to concentrate on adding intensity to their training through compound exercises like squat variations, lunges, deadlifts and kettlebell swings,' Ms Akerberg said.

'They should also add weights to their training. 

'Do not be afraid to lift weights! It will not make you look bulky. Ectomorphs won't need much cardio to remain slim so keep this to low - maximum two days of low intensity circuit training or similar.'

They should also do resistance training three to four days per week and allow more rest time in between sets. 

'Progressive overload (when you increase weight load from week to week) will be a key aspect of an ectomorph's workout to keep on challenging oneself and keep building strength,' Ms Akerberg added.

'It's also important to try to keep stress levels low as high cortisol levels can be disadvantageous for building muscle.'

What should ectomorphs eat?  

Diet wise, ectomorphs will usually have to eat a lot to put on muscle. 

They usually tolerate carbohydrates well, so these people should not be carbohydrate shy when trying to reach their body goals. 

Try and pick fresh and real food alternatives rather than processed carbohydrate variants. 

A keto (no carb, high fat) diet is not recommended for the typical ectomorph. 

THE MESOMORPH - FIT AND FABULOUS 

Celebrity Mesomorphs: Gigi Hadid, Halle Berry 

What is a mesomorph?    

'The mesomorph is a commonly desired body type,' Ms Akerberg said. 

'Mesomorphs are genetically blessed, they are naturally more toned looking and respond well to training. 

'They are naturally strong and muscular and gain muscle easy and lose fat easy. They are known to have a narrow waist but broader shoulders than the ectomorph body type.'

How should they train? 

'Variation is the key! A diverse exercise program suits a mesomorph person well with both cardio and strength training,' Ms Akerberg said.

'Since they are naturally muscular and hold on to muscle mass well this mass will help them burn more calories, even at a resting state. 

'A mix of high-intensity, low intensity steady state cardio and strength training can be quite an effective training approach for a person with a dominance in the mesomorph body type.

What should mesomorphs eat?  

Mesomorphs usually do quite well on a mixed diet (lean proteins, healthy fats and carbohydrates) and have a moderate carbohydrate tolerance. 

Depending on where the person sits on the scale of the somatotype system and depending on the individual, they may respond better to either fats or carbohydrates. It's important to listen to one's body. 

THE ENDOMORPH - CURVALICIOUS 

Celebrity Endomorphs: Kim Kardashian, Beyonce 

What is an endomorph?    

An endomorph body type is usually a larger curvier figure. They are quite commonly a stocky build and their bodies hold onto fat well and find it hard to lose. 

Their chest is wide and bones may be shorter. 

How should they train?    

'An endomorph will need to adopt a new lifestyle to lose fat and keep it off,' Ms Akerberg said.

'Strength training will aid in the muscle-to-fat-ratio which quicken the metabolism. The more muscle one has compared to fat the more calories the person will burn, even at rest. 

'Don't be afraid to lift some weights in the gym! For resistance training - allow little rest time in between sets. To burn more calories and to engage your heart do cardiovascular activities.'

What should endomorphs eat?

Endomorphs should generally lower their carbohydrate intake and consume carbs only around training or as a carb backload approach. 

They usually respond better to a diet higher in fats. 

Endomorphs are prone to inflammation in the body and should be especially careful with consuming inflammatory foods.

What are inflammatory foods?

Vegetable oils (excluding olive, coconut and cocoa)

Margarine

Dairy

Cereals

Meat (especially red meat)

Refined carbohydrates (white flour, white rice, corn and rice cereals)

Gluten

Sugary foods

Peanuts

What are anti-inflammatory foods?

Fish (especially oily fish like salmon and mackerel)

Walnuts

Flaxseed

Leafy green vegetables

Spices and herbs

High fibre foods

Wholefood carbs (vegetables and nuts)

Brightly coloured fruit and vegetables

Berries
item.dc:abstract: Every day it seems as though a new must-try fad diet, superfood or quirky workout is flooding social media feeds the world over. And while these regimes may work for some, there is a far simpler way to stay in shape both inside and out. The trick? Eating and exercising for your particular body shape. Here, FEMAIL speaks to Australian personal trainer, fitness coach and nutrition coach, Camilla Akerberg (left), about these body shapes and the ideal approach to health and fitness for each on. The three types are ectomorphs like Kendall Jenner (centre), mesomorphs like Gigi Hadid (second from right) and endomorphs like Beyonce (right).
item.dc:creator: Chris Lines
item.mi:shortTitle: Are YOU eating right for your body type?

item.title: 'It's humiliating for them, but they learn from it': Mother makes her two 'naughty' daughters sit on the floor in silence in the Tesco fruit and veg aisle for TEN MINUTES
item.description: Louise Palai, from Ilkeston, Derbyshire, said Alisa, six, and Ebony, seven, had been running around and making too much noise. She punished them by making them sit with their heads down.
item.content:encoded:
A mother punished her two daughters for misbehaving in Tesco by making them sit in silence for ten minutes - in the middle of the fruit and veg aisle.

Louise Palai, from  Ilkeston, Derbyshire, said daughters Alisa, six, and Ebony, seven, had been running around the store and making too much noise.

She punished them in public by making them sit with their heads down for ten minutes, while in the supermarket.

The mother, 35, insisted the tactic she adopted was better than smacking or shouting, adding that the punishment was 'humiliating' for her children - but that they 'learn from it'.

Louise, an Avon representative, explained: 'They don't mess about again when you make them sit in the supermarket.   

'They suddenly start behaving as they know everybody can see them.'

She said her daughters needed to learn to behave when out in public, and forcing them to have a time out.  

'Even if they were messing around in the street or in the Intu [shopping] centre, I would get them to do the same thing,' Louise said. 

'No matter how many people are around, they would be forced to sit down and think about that they are doing.

'There were a few people giving me some odd looks, but I don't care what anybody thinks. 

'This method works and it is a much better alternative to shouting at the girls in the middle of the street or smacking them like I have seen other parents do.' 

Louise explained she had previously used the same method at home, making them sit on the stairs to calm them down. 

When out and about though, the youngsters have been forced to take a time out at other stores including Primark in Derby and York.  as well as the Albion Centre.

Louise said: 'No matter where you go, there is always a step they can sit on, but if there is no step there is always the floor.

'At home we have a naughty step and if the children start messing about I tell them to sit on the stairs to calm down.

'My eldest daughter is fourteen now, but when she was 12 she also had to sit down in Tesco, as she had been messing about.'

She added: 'Sitting them down in the shop means they are seen by loads of people and it is humiliating for them, but they learn from it.

'It annoys me when you see youngsters running around and causing a nuisance to people, I want my kids to know the different between what is and isn't acceptable behaviour when they are in public.

'I would encourage other parents to do the same thing. If their kids are having a tantrum, they soon learn that there will be consequences for their behaviour.'

Other parents have since praised Louise for the tactic she used to get her children to be behave.

One commented: 'That's excellent parenting right there. Absolutely right that form of punishment is much better than smacking or even idle threats.' 

Another added: 'Parents of the UK listen to this woman. Kids need discipline and they clearly love their mum more for it. So good to see kids having respect for their parents.'
item.dc:abstract: Louise Palai, from Ilkeston, Derbyshire, (left, with daughters Ebony and Alisa) said daughters Alisa, six, and Ebony, seven, had been running around the store and making too much noise. She punished them in public by making them sit with their heads down in silence for ten minutes (right), while in the supermarket. The mother, 35, insisted that the tactic she adopted was better than smacking or shouting.
item.dc:creator: Emily Chan
item.mi:shortTitle: Mother makes two daughters sit on the floor in silence in the Tesco

item.title: Would you pay $820,000 for this dress? 'World's rarest gown' made with hundreds of precious Australian pearls makes fashion history
item.description: An Australian jewellery designer has made fashion history by showcasing a ‘once-in-a-lifetime’ gown. She adorned the dress with rare Australian Keshi pearls valued at $820,000.
item.content:encoded:
When getting ready on a Friday night, it's unlikely a dress worth a cool AUD$820,000 is sitting in your closet. 

But if you have the cash to splash there is one dress that will certainly have you standing out from the crowd.

A renowned Australian jewellery designer has made fashion history by helping to bring to life a 'once-in-a-lifetime' lavender gown.

Margot McKinney adorned the dress with rare and precious Australian Keshi south sea pearls.

'We believe this is the world's rarest gown,' Ms McKinney said.

'Taking into account the extreme rarity of these natural pearls and the sheer artistry of their placement with such meticulous precision - it is pure perfection.'

The gown is a collaboration between designer CD Greene and Ms McKinney and was their attempt at recalling the elegant glamour of movie star Grace Kelly. 

It features lavender thistle silk and a body skimming design and a show-stopping collar, which is where the pearls are sewn.

The intention of the dress was for it to grace the body luxuriously and echo the glamour of the 50s and 60s.

The encrusted collar is the focal point of the detachable cape, which can be removed to reveal the back that is embellished with pearls and crystals. 

Mr Greene said the stunning Australian pearls offered up a plethora of different design ideas.

He particularly wanted to encapsulate a level of exotic luxury the fashion world had 'never seen' before.

'The natural irregular shape of the Keshi pearls was really inspiring to work with as a medium, and it offered a beautiful, ornate juxtaposition with the effortless clean lines of the dress,' he said.

These treasures of the sea are so exotic, so rare, that the idea of putting them on a dress, especially this many of them, is unheard of.'  

The gown is on display this month in New York City's Bergdorf Goodman.
item.dc:abstract: When getting ready on a Friday you're not often looking to spend over $800,000, but if you have the cash there is one dress that will have you standing out from the crowd (left, right and inset). A renowned Australian jewellery designer has recently made fashion history by showcasing this ‘once-in-a-lifetime’ lavender gown. Margot McKinney adorned the dress with rare and precious Australian Keshi south sea pearls valued at $820,000.
item.dc:creator: Laura House
item.mi:shortTitle: Would you pay $820,000 for this dress?

item.title: From decanting spices to storing tomatoes in the crisper: FEMAIL reveals the everyday kitchen items you are storing the WRONG way
item.description: FEMAIL breaks down the pointers that can not only help you organise your kitchen to perfection, but keep its contents fresher for longer.
item.content:encoded:
Everyone has a different system as to how they arrange their kitchen, but not every way is correct.

In fact, there are some particular ground rules we should all be following when it comes to storing food and utensils. 

Here, FEMAIL breaks down the pointers that can not only help you organise your kitchen to perfection, but keep its contents fresher for longer. 

STOP DECANTING YOUR SPICES

Many people like to find decorative containers to store their spices, but experts from Apartment Therapy have deemed it completely unnecessary.

Not only with it take people a long time to do, there is no proof that it will make them last longer.

Doing this can also make your spices take up a lot more space than necessary. 

NEVER KEEP MILK IN THE FRIDGE DOOR

While 99 per cent of us might keep our milk in the door of the fridge for ease of use and simplicity's sake, according to Choice dairy is far better off on the bottom shelf.

'Everyone keeps milk in the door, but this is actually the warmest part of the fridge,' they revealed in a video on the subject.

Instead, milk will last far longer if you keep it on the bottom shelf, where it's cooler. Milk is best stored at or below four degrees Celsius. 

STOP PUTTING TOMATO SAUCE IN THE CUPBOARD 

Dipping chips in cold ketchup may not be to your taste, but scientists say keeping it in the cupboard has health risks.

‘No one kept tomato ketchup in the fridge a decade ago, but then it contained more salt,’ Dr Peter Barratt of Initial Hygiene previously told Femail.

‘In recent years, food manufacturers have cut the amount of salt, a natural preservative, because of its links to high blood pressure.’

But a lack of salt means ketchup is prone to decay, a process accelerated when high temperatures help food poisoning bacteria to thrive. Storing it in the fridge slows this down and makes the sauce last longer

DON'T PUT TOMATOES IN THE CRISPER

According to Choice, the crisper - an enclosed drawer at the bottom of fridges - shouldn't store tomatoes.

Although it has specifically been designed to keep fruit and vegetables fresh and ready to eat for several days, tomatoes shouldn't be included. 

'Your tomatoes don't belong in your fridge - keeping them in a fruit bowl on the counter keeps them bursting with flavour,' Choice revealed. 

DON'T THROW YOUR KNIVES INTO A DRAWER

According to Nine Honey people need to stop throwing their knives into their kitchen drawers.

This is because doing so could dull the knife blades, as well as create a safety issue that could see eager hands cutting themselves as they reach inside.

It is better to put them on a magnetic strip or buy a knife block to put them in. 

REMOVE CANNED GOODS FROM THE PANTRY

Although there is nothing unsafe with storing canned food in the pantry, it often means that people forget what they have.

This means when shopping people tend to buy certain cans a second time or miss their use by date.

Nine Honey recommend using a magazine storage rack and place the oldest cans towards the front and the newer cans towards the back.

This means home cooks will constantly be using the ones that are closest to their use by date.

DON'T STACK CAST IRON PANS

Nine Honey also explained that people should avoid stacking pans on top of each other when storing them in the cupboard.

This is due to the fact that when you place metal on top of metal it scratches it, causing irreparable damage.

They suggested putting a sheet of paper towel between each pan to prevent friction.   

KEEP BULBS OUT OF SUNLIGHT

If you've been leaving garlic bulbs out on the worktops, they'll be going off much quicker.

You should store garlic and onions in a bamboo steamer, giving them a cool, well ventilated home that protects them from the light.

This will prevent sprouting, which means they’ll be edible for much longer.
item.dc:abstract: Everyone has a different system as to how they arrange their kitchen, but not every way is correct. There are some particular ground rules we should be following when it comes to storing food and utensils. Here, FEMAIL breaks down the pointers that can not only help you organise your kitchen to perfection, but keep its contents fresher for longer. This includes not keeping your milk in your fridge door and not stacking cast iron pans.

item.title: They WON'T be beaten! Hilarious snaps capture people who REFUSE to follow the rules - and their very creative ways of breaking them
item.description: People from around the world have taken to Bored Panda to share snaps of the creative ways they had devised to side-step authority.
item.content:encoded:
A hilarious online gallery captures the work of rule-breakers who refuse to be told what to do. 

People from around the world have taken toBored Panda to share snaps of the creative ways they had devised to side-step authority.  

A college couple who were banned from having members of the opposite sex in their dormitory after dark decided to continue with movie night by sitting outside together to watch a TV through an open window.

And two friends who weren't allowed cans of beer by the pool created an extra-long straw to allow them to sip away.  

Scroll down to see some of the best examples...

item.title: Single office worker, 27, who was labelled a 'big girl' moonlights as a WRESTLER - but admits men won't date her as they find her intimidating
item.description: Kimberley Benson, 27, from Scotland, works for her family business by day, and by night she is a champion wrestler. In BBC One's Fight Like A Girl she explains what it's like leading a double life.
item.content:encoded:
By day, Kimberly Benson dons a smart blouse and jacket for her job at the family coach hire firm. 

But by night, the 27-year-old is body slamming opponents in Lycra and fishnets as she steps into the wrestling ring as her alter-ego: Viper: The Vixen of Violence.

Kim, from Kilbirnie, Aryshire, has spent more than a decade forging her career as a wrestler, despite being 'written off' by industry professionals because she is a 'big girl'. 

Wrestling has taken her across the UK and around the world, with tournaments in France, Germany, America and Japan - where she has a legion of fans.

The contrast between her two worlds is not lost on Kim, who explains exactly what it’s like to lead her double life in BBC One's new documentary Fight Like A Girl, which airs on Monday night. 

Kim, who is 5ft 5in and weighs 14st 8lb, also speaks of the challenges of breaking into what was once a very male-dominated industry. 

She says: 'When I first started training for wrestling, certainly in my school there wasn’t many other girls. All the wrestlers that were on television were all "supermodels".

'Women’s wrestling was just not respected. It was difficult for me as a girl and because I was a big girl. I think a lot of people are surprised when I am there because they take one look at me and think "she’s not going to last five minutes"…

'But I am really, really proud of that. So proud of the stigma that I had for it, so proud that I didn’t let people’s snide comments get to me.' 

Kim fell in love with the sport as a child and started attending a nearby wrestling school when she was 16. 

She now competes in up to four matches a week and has made tens of thousands of pounds taking on both male and female wrestlers.

However Kim explains that her success has come at a personal cost.

She tells how she often misses out on family birthdays, her nephews growing up - and doesn't have the time to commit to a relationship. 

She says: 'Some people say that being in the spotlight is the loneliest place in the world. 

'It’s hard to build relationships when you don’t know if you’re going to be on the other side of the world. That’s the hard part of it, you belong to everybody and nobody.'

But she also loves what she does, adding: 'Travelling the world and living your dream - you can't beat that.'

In an interview with The Sun, Kim added that she believes her strong attitude intimidates men and has left her unable to find love. 

She says: 'Men find it really intimidating knowing I could beat them up or lift them over my head. I’m also a big girl and a big personality, so it will take a special guy.

'I am a big lady and lot of guys don’t like that. I am very driven. Sometimes men feel that they can’t live up to that and it scares them off.'

Kim, who has earned tens of thousands of pounds through wrestling, has her sights set on one day joining WWE, the global wrestling brand and pinnacle of the sport. 

The programme shows Kim training for a double world title bout in Japan.

She admits she initially struggled when competing in Asia because of how her frame made her standout in a crowd. 

But now she is regularly stopped by fans desperate to snap a selfie with their favourite wrestler. 

She competes against her friend and fellow wrestler Toni Storm, scooping the prestigious title of Stardom World Alliance' overall World Champion.

It's an emotional moment for a dedicated Kim as she breaks down crying happy tears: 'It feels really amazing. I can’t express some of the things I have gone through in my wrestling career, people wrote me off a lot because of my size and what I look like. 

'They thought because I was big and some sort of blonde girl that was never going to get anywhere and now I have two belts from the top companies in the world.'

She added: 'I never thought a farm girl would be sitting in Japan having won two of the prestigious championships and travelling the world and living my dream. Is there anything better?'

Fight Like A Girl airs Monday 11 June on BBC One at 7.30pm

item.title: These stunning modern homes are hiding a very quirky secret - so can you guess what sets them apart from every other property on the market?
item.description: While the idea of owning a home is somewhat of a faraway dream for millennials, in the meantime it's worthwhile visiting these rental properties with an ingenious twist.
item.content:encoded:
For many a millennial the idea of owning a home is somewhat of a faraway dream.

But in the meantime you can enjoy the vast space and comfort of a rental property - particularly ones made out of quirky shipping containers.

This intricately designed home sits on the edge of a hillside in Wellington, its large frame complimented by vast windows and a crisp white exterior, Nine Travel reports.

It was made possible by stacking three three 40-foot shipping containers perched one on top of the other.

Known as 'The Wellington Container House', it looks stark from the roadside but inside boasts plush leather lounges, timber flooring and a modern staircase.

It can house up to eight guests in three bedrooms, two bathrooms and an outdoor bathhouse with a hot tub.

If that doesn't seem fancy enough there is a pool table to really bring the family together and a cinema in case you're after a more relaxed evening indoors.

It's just $250 a night for what is an excellent holiday home - winter or summer months included. 

The Mini Whananaki Beach House is made up of 20 different shipping containers - with its name coming from its original use as a Mini Cooper freight.

It has picturesque ocean views from the front and nature-filled bushland behind it, all for $850 a night.

But if you're sweating over the price, fear not, more than 30 people can sleep in the luxury quarters with 14 beds scattered across six bedrooms and three bathrooms.

The kitchen, outdoor barbecue area and slick, minimalistic interiors are all a high point with customers.

So why are shipping container homes becoming so popular?

Ultimately they provide an excellent framework in which to 'case' your belongings - almost like a shell - and at a cheaper rate than you'll find most other traditional houses on the market. 

They're extremely durable and tough in terms of weather safety and can be curated in an eco-friendly way for those wanting to live 'off the grid.'

However, if you live by the ocean shipping containers may not be your first choice of estate - mainly because the metal can corrode the exterior over time.

The structural integrity of the building can also be damaged by cutting into the containers for doors and windows.
item.dc:abstract: While the idea of owning a home is somewhat of a faraway dream for millennials, in the meantime it's worthwhile visiting these rental properties with an ingenious twist. Plush interiors set with black leather lounges (left) and walls made entirely of windows (right) can be yours for as little as $250 a night.

item.title: Pregnant woman is left feeling 'ugly' because her husband REFUSES to have sex with her - but other parents think SHE'S being unreasonable
item.description: Writing on Mumsnet, the British woman, who is 18 weeks pregnant, explained her husband believes it would be 'wrong' because their unborn baby might be able to tell what is happening.
item.content:encoded:
A mother-to-be has revealed her husband refuses to have sex with her while she is expecting.

Writing on Mumsnet, the British woman, who is 18 weeks pregnant, explained her partner claims it would be 'wrong' because their unborn baby might be able to tell what is happening.

However his decision has left her feeling 'ugly and unattractive'. She asked: 'AIBU [am I being unreasonable] to be gutted by this?'

The post divided opinion on the online forum, with some agreeing that they would be frustrated if they were in her position. However others argued she was the one who was being unreasonable for placing the expectation on her husband.  

She wrote: 'DP won't have sex even though I'm only 18 weeks. Says he's not comfortable with it as he thinks baby can tell. 

'I've told him otherwise and shown him the research to go with it. We haven't had sex since baby was conceived as he thinks it is "wrong". He won't look at me and I just feel ugly and unattractive.

'I'm not saying he has to have sex with me, of course. Nobody should do anything they aren't comfortable with. AIBU however to be gutted by this? 9 months of no sex and then some.

'I'm considering ordering from love honey as if he ain't giving it to me then I'll do it myself!'

One sympathetic woman wrote: 'If he truly loved and fancied you he wouldn't stop wanting to make love. Some of the best sex was during my pregnancies.'

Another said: 'You are not being unreasonable. I was rampant when I was pregnant, couldn't get enough much to darling partner's delight. Obviously we were gentle and careful but it was a really special time for us and he loved my changing body and bump... I would feel upset about losing closeness for so long.'

Some suggested ways she might be able to help reassure her husband. 

One posted: 'Maybe your DH [darling husband] might feel differently if you get the doctor or midwife to reassure him. Alternatively show him this thread. I'm not surprised you're upset. It's horrible to feel your dearest husband doesn't find you attractive.'

Another suggested: 'Maybe wear a baggy t shirt/ sexy nightie to camouflage your bump? Out of sight, out of mind?' 

However she came under fire from other users who slammed her for questioning her husband's feelings in the situation.  

One person said: 'You are being unreasonable, if he doesn't want to have sex then you should respect that. I found it bizarre when I was pregnant and we didn't have sex at all! Luckily my husband didn't question me.'

Another warned it could be a sign of future trouble.  

They wrote: 'No one should feel obliged to have sex just because their partner wants it, obviously. But a man who goes off sex when his wife is pregnant... that can be an indicator of long term trouble ahead...' 

The mother-to-be later shared a second post clarifying that she was not forcing her husband to have sex.
item.dc:abstract: Writing on Mumsnet, the British woman, who is 18 weeks pregnant, explained her husband believes it would be 'wrong' because their baby might be able to tell what is happening. However his decision has left her feeling 'ugly and unattractive'. The post divided opinion on the online forum.
